clinical_study.brief_title: Motion Analysis of Delirium in the ICU
clinical_study.official_title: Motion Analysis of Delirium in Intensive Care Units

brief_summary.textblock: Delirium, as a common complication of hospitalization, poses significant health problems in hospitalized patients. Though about a third of delirium cases can benefit from intervention, detecting and predicting delirium is still very limited in practice. A common characterization of delirium is changes in activity level, causing patients to become hyperactive or hypoactive which is manifested in facial expressions and total body movements. This pilot study is designed to test the feasibility of a delirium detection system using movement data obtained from 3-axis wearable accelerometers and Microsoft Kinect sensor, in conjunction with electronics medical record (EMR) data to analyze the relation of whole-body movement as well as facial expressions with delirium.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of the study is to assess the potential of motion and facial expression data for detecting delirium in ICU patients by comparing motion and facial expression patterns in delirium and control group. In this study, the investigators will use ActivePalTM accelerometer to record each subject's movement patterns. Also, a processed video using the KINECT application-programming interface to identify patient facial expressions and movement patterns. A total of 40 participants will be enrolled with delirium and 20 patients without delirium will be used as control group. Motion profiles will be compared in the motorically defined subgroups (hyperactive, hypoactive, normal) based on accelerometer and Kinect data. Then differences in facial expression, number of changes in postures and percentage of time spent moving between motorically defined subgroups and in delirium and control group. EMR data will also be used to assess the feasibility of detecting delirium by additionally including information on related risk factors.

primary_outcome.measure: Delirium Rating Scale Revised-98 (DRS-R98) will be used for changes from baseline up to 7 days between the groups.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: DRS-R98 is a 16-item scale with a maximum total scale score of 46 points and a maximum severity score of 39 points.

primary_outcome.measure: Memorial Delirium Assessment Scale (MDAS) will be used for changes from baseline up to 7 days between the groups.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: MDAS denotes motor profile and defines motor subtyping. It has 10 items which assesses several areas of cognitive functioning (memory, attention, orientation and disturbances in thinking) and psychomotor activity. The items are rated on a four point scale (0-3) based on the current interaction with the patient or by assessment of behavior. A score of 13 shows the diagnosis of delirium.

primary_outcome.measure: Delirium Motor Subtyping Scale (DMSS-4) will be used for changes from baseline up to 7 days between the groups.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: Scoring from DMSS-4 which has 5 hyperactive and 8 hypoactive symptoms requires at least two symptoms to be present from either the hyperactive or hypoactive list to meet subtype criteria. The higher the score the higher the delirium.

secondary_outcome.description: Death at any time during admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of subjects on mechanical ventilation
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects requiring mechanical ventilation greater than 48 hours.

other_outcome.measure: Facial amimia versus non-amimic expressions between the groups
other_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
other_outcome.description: Frequency of presence of facial amimia versus non-amimic expressions between the groups.

other_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
other_outcome.description: Percentage of time spent moving versus static position

arm_group.description: ICU patients with a positive Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) score; Thigh accelerometer; Kinect for Windows sensor
ICU patients with a negative Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) score; Thigh accelerometer; Kinect for Windows sensor

study_pop.textblock: Patients who been hospitalized in an intensive care unit and have risk factors to develop delirium or delirium has been suspected by their medical provider.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Intensive care unit patient
- 18 years of age or older
- Eligibility confirmed within 24 hours of admission
- Positive Confusion Assessment Method score
Exclusion Criteria:
- Anticipated intensive care unit stay less than one day
- Less than 18 years of age
- Inability to wear a motion sensor watch (ActivPal)
